title: 106_s1704
content: The Act may be cited as the "Access to High Standards Act." The "Access to High Standards Act" acknowledges the need for improved academic preparation in secondary schools, highlighting issues such as limited employment opportunities, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation for incoming college freshmen. The Act emphasizes the importance of raising academic standards and establishing high expectations in public education, with a focus on modeling standards after advanced placement programs. These programs offer a variety of college-level courses, are widely endorsed by education leaders and states, and have a significant impact on a diverse student population. The advanced placement programs offer college-level courses to a diverse student population, with over 1,000,000 students benefiting from the program. 24 states are funding initiatives to increase participation in advanced placement programs, including providing funds for teacher professional development and paying test fees for students. These programs have shown positive responsiveness from schools and students. The Advanced Placement programs in various states have shown success in increasing enrollment, achievement, and minority participation. The Act aims to encourage more students to take AP exams and build on the benefits of the program for students, including acquiring important skills valued by employers. The Act aims to encourage students to take AP exams to demonstrate their achievements, build on program benefits like acquiring important skills, raising academic standards, increasing program availability, and diversifying student participation. The Act aims to increase availability and diversity in advanced placement programs, especially for low-income and disadvantaged students. It also aims to increase participation rates in advanced placement courses for secondary school juniors and seniors. Increase participation in advanced placement programs for secondary school juniors and seniors, aiming for 25% of the student population to be involved and to boost the number of students receiving college credit for their test scores. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary awards grants to eligible entities for 3 years to carry out authorized activities. Eligible entities are State or local educational agencies. Priority is given to entities showing a need for advanced placement programs and involving business and community organizations. Priority is given to eligible entities demonstrating a need for advanced placement programs, involving business and community organizations, having matching funds from State or local sources, focusing on English, mathematics, and science programs, and targeting schools with a high concentration of low-income students. An eligible entity may use grant funds to expand access to advanced placement programs for low-income students through teacher training, course development, curriculum coordination, supplies, and other related activities. The eligible entity can use grant funds for various purposes, including preparing students for advanced placement courses, curriculum development, providing books and supplies, and expanding access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals. To apply for a grant, the entity must submit an application to the Secretary. Additionally, data collection and reporting requirements include information on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, tests taken, test scores, and demographic information. The Secretary will compile and report annually to Congress on information received from eligible entities regarding the number of advanced placement tests taken, test scores, and demographic data. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for on-line advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students without access to such courses. Grant funds can be used for curriculum purchase, teacher training, or course materials. Applications for grants are required from interested agencies. Grant funds provided under this section can be used to purchase online curriculum, train teachers, or buy course materials. Local educational agencies must submit applications to the Secretary to receive grants. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. Each institution of higher education receiving Federal funds must distribute information to secondary school counselors or advanced placement coordinators regarding academic credit for advanced placement test scores. They are also required to standardize the form and manner of disseminating this information within four years. Additionally, there are amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 related to Javits gifted and talented students. State and Local Initiatives amend various education acts to prioritize programs for gifted and talented students that incorporate advanced placement courses and tests, as well as focus on increasing student participation and success in advanced placement courses. The Secretary shall prioritize grants for upward bound projects focusing on increasing student participation in advanced placement courses. Additionally, federal activities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 will prioritize training in advanced placement instruction. State and local initiatives will also prioritize programs for gifted and talented students that include advanced placement courses. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include professional development activities for advanced placement instruction. Technology grants encourage delivering advanced placement instruction to underserved communities. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include education technology grants for providing advanced placement instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include education technology grants for advanced placement instruction. The amendment specifies that the project must use education technology for advanced placement instruction. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like "advanced placement incentive program" for providing activities to low-income individuals, "advanced placement test" administered by the College Board, "high concentration of low-income students" for schools with 40% or more low-income students, and "low-income individual" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "low-income individual" in the Act refers to a person who meets the criteria outlined in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and is academically prepared to take an advanced placement test. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965, while terms like "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" have specific meanings as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and the term "State" includes various entities such as states, territories, and other jurisdictions within the United States.
